item.title: Upgrading Emacs to 24.5
item.description:
Dump this in your terminal:

sudo apt-get install checkinstall
mkdir -p ~/src
cd ~/src
wget https://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/emacs/emacs-24.5.tar.gz
tar xf emacs-24.5.tar.gz
cd emacs-24.5
./configure
make
sudo checkinstall

item.title: How to enable SSH access to Synology DiskStation
item.description: Log into your system with an administrator account and open the 1Control Panel applet. From there, click on 2Terminal & SNMP, 3Enabled SSH service, and 4Apply.

item.title: How to setup automated backups to SSH server with Synology DiskStation
item.description: As a best practice, it’s great great to have your data in more than one location. I use my Synology Diskation as a local network file server at my home. The reality is something can happen and I lose all my important data in that little box. From a BBQ, a birthday party, or maybe the house just burns down and now all my data is gone. Unfortunately my network rack at home will never be as secure as a network rack in a data center. So, backup your data because that’s much easier to do rather than trying to restore from no backup. Makes logical sense right? Derp.

item.title: Replace a bad hard drive on a Synology DiskStation RAID 5 with DSM 5.0
item.description: I received an alert from my Synology RAID regarding a few bad sectors on a hard drive. Even though the RAID is still operational, it’s best practice to replace the hard drive before any data gets corrupted due to the bad sectors.

item.title: Update Chef Solo on your Vagrant
item.description: Install vagrant-omnibus: vagrant plugin install vagrant-omnibus Configure your Vagrantfile before provisioning to the latest version of Chef: config.omnibus.chef_version = :latest You can also upgrade to a specific version like so: config.omnibus.chef_version = "11.12.8"

item.title: Backing up and Restoring with MongoDB
item.description: Dump You can dump the database locally using the following mongodump: mongodump --host DATABASE_HOST --port PORT -d YOUR_DATABASE_NAME -u YOUR_DB_USERNAME -p YOUR_DB_PASSWORD This will create a dump folder containing a subfolder named after your database. The default port for MongoDB is 27017. Import You can import the same dump to a local MongoDB instance using something like the following mongorestore after changing into the dump directory: mongorestore --host DATABASE_HOST --port PORT -d DATABASE_NAME_TO_IMPORT_TO --drop DATABASE_NAME_TO_IMPORT_FROM Note: This will drop the collections in the DATABASE_NAME_TO_IMPORT_TO database before restoring the same collections from your database dump.
